bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, September 6, 1921

div1.p: In a report on the yellow fever work in Peru, Hanson discusses financial matters, correspondence received, the help extended by White and Carter, and manpower needs. Hanson declares the campaign is going well.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, September 6, 1921
div1.opener:
Chiclayo, Peru.
September 6, 1921.
Dr. Wicliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York City.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
I am surpirsed to note by your letter of May 26, that the
Peruvian Consul in New York had charged you to the amount of $80.00 on the
shipment of serum and vaccine for Peru. I will take this matter up at the
earliest possible opportunity, and feel quite certain that instructions will
be given without delay that these charges be remitted, and that there be no
further charges on materials of this kind. I will write the Salubridad about
the matter and follow the thing up when I get to Lima on my next trip.

In your letter of May 21, you speak of an advance of $30,000, in
addition to previous appropriations. According to my records I have had $35,000,
received here in addition to the $5,000, which I cashed in the National City
Bank in Lima, before coming up to take complete charge of the Campaign. In
addition to this there is the $500, which you gave to Corrigan and Pickett.
Up to date we have not been able to turn in a detailed statement of the funds
used in the Province of Trujillo, because at first I was hoping that the Govern-
ment would advance sufficient funds to keep that section going, and in order not
to have any interruption in the work there I advanced certain sums there from time
to time, which we entered in the local books, as money advanced (dinero adelantado
en calidad de prestamo) thinking that we would be able to reimburse these funds
from money received from the Government. This we have never been able to do. For
this reason as soon as Mr. Guldstarnd has the accounts for this section checked
we will send them on and he will go on to check up on the Province of Pacasmayo,
and to examine the accounts for the Province of Trujillo and the balance of the
2. W.R., I.H.B., September 6, 1921.
campaign to the south. We will then send you a complete resume of expenditures
up to the end of the month of August.

I think that it will be necessary to have an available working capital
of about $10,000, a month. I cabled you to this effect yesterday, copy of cable
enclosed. Were it not for the fact that we may be obliged to take all of the
employees on your payroll, we might get along with less. With the exchange as it
is now it works very much to our adavantage so far as all native employees, and
local expenses are concerned. In regard to the exchange however, the local banks
do not give me the same rate as the Lima Banks do. This matter was discussed with
Mr. Calvin of the National City Bank in Lima, who suggested that I convert all my
money there in order to get the best rate. The trouble with this is the rates
which these local banks charge on taking Lima checks,- I will investigate this
further. Some time ago .August 4th, I cashed $4500, here and got a rate of $3.0,
while about the same time the pound was selling in Lima for about $3.20, repre-
senting a difference of about Lp 82.7.20.

I believe that it will be possible to reduce the expenses considerably
from now on. It certainly would if we could get the Government to come across with
pay for the Medical Officers. I received a wireless from the Salubridad the day
after I returned asking how much they owed me, which I presume they think should
should encourage me to think that they are thinking about paying me. I replied
indicating the months which were due but have heard nothing further. I do not like
the idea of being obliged to take my salary out of your funds if it can be avoided.
However I was compelled to send Mrs. Hanson some more funds, and sent her a check
on the Equitable Trust Co., Check # 19, for $500. (five hundred) which I marked
chargable to salary of Director Yellow Fever Campaign Peru. If the Government pays
I will return this amount to the working capital of the campaign. I took the
liberty of doing this on the strength of your cable to me in Panama, as follows:

HANSON CARE CHIEF HEALTH OFFICER BALBOA
SALARY YOURSELF AND EMPLOYEES FROM ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION FUNDS
APPROVED IN ACCORDANCE WITH KIRKS LETTER JUNE THIRD
EMPLOY DUNN IF YOU NEED HIM PERU
INTERCOM.
#3. W.R., I.H.B., September 6, 1921.

I am glad to note what you say about the progress in Mexico. Are they
using fish freely? Fish distributed freely and properly controlled is the surest
and quickest method of control that I know of, and I think that we have tried every-
thing else that seems practical. I enclose two reports from Mr. Corrigan of his
work in the south which I believe you will find interesting. In this you will note
that we have also used tadpoles and shrimps.

Re your letter of May 23 introducing Dr. Hoffman, I am sorry not to have
had the opportunity of meeting him. I received a letter from him addressed to me
at Lima, but this letter also reached me a long time after the date which he had
set for his visit to Lima. I wrote him at the home office as I did not have any
other way of being certain of eventually reaching him.

Re your letter of May 27, advising me of Dr. Whites coming, I wish to re-
iterate what I have already said that I was very glad indeed to meet him and to
have him see what and how we were doing our work. I am always ready to profit by
the experience of men who know more about the work than I do, and it is a real
pleasure to be associated with men like Dr. White and Dr. Carter, they know a
thing when they see it. Dr. Carter's presence here last year and the first part
of this was vital to the final outcome of the campaign, it can not be overestimated.
I discussed my plans freely with Dr. White and believe that we are quite agreed as
to the procedure for the future.

Miss Read speaks in her letter of June 21, of the circulars number 122
and 122-A which I sent up, and says that they have been referred to the Comptrollers
Office. In a campaign of this kind with as many changes as we have had a circular
soon becomes obsolete. Both of these have been considerably modified since that date.

Miss read in her letter of June 29, speaks hopefully of the resulst of my
interview with the President in regard to funds. I also hoped, and now am doing the
“watchful waiting”. I have Mr. Kirk's letters of May 13 and June 3 to which she
refers.

In regard to the cable referred in the letter of July 12, i received one
copy in ample time and suffered no inconvenience due to the slight delay.
4. W.R., I.H.B., September 6, 1921.

In Miss Read's letter of July 14, she speaks of the translation of Dr.
Carter's lecture on yellow fever. We also have made a translation of the same
article, and in addition also the first lecture. I will send you a copy of this
translation. Our Interpretor is a Columbian and I think an unusually good translator.
He has read the translation made by you and pronounces it very good. He has a few
minor differences but nothing of importance. We are preparing a list of persons
whom we think may be interested in this article.

I have your copy of letter to Dr. White under date of July 16, which I
doubt that he received before leaving. I also found three other letters form him
from the International Health Board on my return. I have forwarded all these to
him in Washington.

In this letter you speak of sporadic cases in eastern Mexico. If we
should have any more cases here they will be sporadic cases among the small places
which you will note on the map of Lambayeque up near or in the foothills of the
mountains. Even if this does occur it is very doubtful that we will ever hear of
them because there is no medical assistance in that section. I do not think it is
worthwhile to spend any money in that section for the present at least. We have the
entire coast down to less than one percent of breeding with very few exceptions, and
in no place that I know of either in Lambayeque of Libertad do we have over 2% of
the containers breading. From Corrigans reports it seems that the Department of
Ancash is already controlled. Before the end of the month we will tackle the north-
ern part of the Department of Lima. If you think that we are spreading out too much
I trust you will criticise freely.

In your letter of July 20, you motion statistical reports. We have sent
you what we had of the officially confirmed cases from the Department of Libertad.
These are more nearly complete that those we have from the Department of Lambayeque
but at that they also are incomplete. Our officially confirmed cases here in this
department are only a few hundred, which is a small fraction of what the total
actually was. We are checking up as much as possible on these and will send you
5. W.R., I.H.B., September 6, 1921.
copies. We are working up certain maps and records which we think important, of
which I presume Dr. White will have told you before you receive this.

The blanks to which you refer (vaccination blanks) I have never received.
We have taken certain records and will forward copies as I presume you wish these
for your files.

In regard to Corrigan and Pickett, I discussed this matter with Dr. White
and we dicided that it was justifiable to keep them on for a little longer until
we should have the coast particularly well surveyed. The have done most excellent
work, and have been worth almost twice what ordinary less trained men would have
been worth. They have the big advantage of their last years campaign, both in know-
ing the people and the peculiarities of the local breeding conditions. It is also a
big advantage to me in having some men that I know with certainty that I can de-
pend on in any detail that I assign them. However as I stated in my cable I shall
terminate their services as soon as possible after the arrival of Mr. Dunn who I
will use in the south, with his headquarters in Huacho.

In regard to your letter of the 29th of July quoting cables, I beg to say
that I have taken note of your attitude in regard to furnishing funds, and I hope
the Government will appreciate it. When I get to Lima I will see what can be
gotten there. In so far as the epidemic is concerned it seems to be over. However
we are still carrying on our work as though it were not yet over.

Your letter of August 8th has also been received. I am glad to say that
that incident has been happily closed. I am told that this letter at first occasioned
the threat of a challenge to a duel.

Trusting that I may be able to continue giving as good a report, and with
a reiteration of my gratitude for your help and advice,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Henry Hanson,
Director of Campaign.
